comments.value: We are interested in testing the positioning of elements on the homepage. we would like to create a second version (call it index2) that switches the position of news/blog tabs and the webcams/videos tab.  There is a new feature in google that can direct half of our traffic to the index2 page and the other to our current page, and we can then test the performance of both!  Can you let me know how much work the swap and new page would be?  Do you have any other concerns with the idea?

Hi Liz,

A/B testing !

Sounds like a great idea, will really give you a feel for what is working before you make any lasting changes, in effect free user testing !

And yes, we can certainly get this set-up for you, hopefully without breaking the bank..

We could do this by altering the existing template to render slightly differentially on a random basis and setting the Google analytics tag as appropriate for each version. But this could mean the existing home page template gets cluttered up and bugs introduced, so..

I think my preferred approach (I think the same as what you are suggesting) would be to keep the main home page as the master and then have an alternative versions (that are *never* manually linked to in the CMS or else we could hit issues when we delete the alternatives) each with a different Google tag to mark the variation and then set-up a redirect on the front end of the site to randomly alternate users between the different versions over a period of time. This keeps our existing master template untouched.

So:

- create alternative home page template, with news/video flipped (we could possibly have more than one variation)
- update google analytics code on both versions as appropriate for GA A/B testing
- create an alternative home page indexb.html that is never linked to in the CMS
- setup workflow to repurposes the manually assigned content from the master home page into the alternative version.
- setup workflow to publish the repurposing when the main version is republished.
- setup a redirect on the front end to seamlessly (ie. hidden to the user) deliver alternate versions on a 50/50 (random) basis.
- test / deploy
- remove redirect / alternative template and pages and update master Google tag on main home page after a given period and revert everything back to normal.

I think being realistic that's probably *a day and a half's work* to get it all set up and tested so we are happy to run with it (and also time spent taking it down afterwards) 

Although we'll leave all the redirects and stuff in place / commented out so you can easily run further tests in future (and much more cheaply, basically only our time spent tweaking the alternative version of the template, which I imagine is no more 0.5 day for an small to medium changes).

Lets have a chat if you need clarification on anything..

Jamie

Jamie,

This all sounds excellent! I'm home today (nasty cold/flu thing) but i'll ring you tomorrow and we can discuss - definitely have a few questions ... just want to make sure I understand all the details!


-----Original Message-----

Done - create alternative home page template, with news/video flipped (we could possibly have more than one variation)
Done - create an alternative home page indexb.html that is never linked to in the CMS
Done - setup workflow to publish the repurposing when the main version is republished.

- setup a redirect on the front end to seamlessly (ie. hidden to the user) deliver alternate versions on a 50/50 (random) basis.

htaccess vs php? If we do this via php then i can take care of this, in case its htaccess i better dont.

Janos, can you pick this up and add in the ness. tags for A/B testing and let me know if i need to set up a redirect at the server level.

thanks

Two things I'd need for that:

1. Some kind of access to google web optimizer. I think they do two flavors, one is (if you've created an experiment already) just a link where I can see the necessary tags I need to add to the page.

2. I don't know how far we're on this - A/B experiments are to compare two or more layouts of the page by measuring how successful are the versions. For this, we need to set up a "goal" and basically measure how many of those goals are reached with each version. The goal is in the case of an e-commerce site would be an order confirmation page (the more goals, the more successful the page). In this case it can be trickier, but would be very useful to find a goal that's fairly general and doesn't change a lot. Jamie mentioned the aim of this specific experiment to increase visits to the webcams (page), is it correct?

Also, has someone read the instructions here:
https://www.google.com/analytics/siteopt/ab_checklist?account=1925888 I
think we'll need a 'target page'? (Probably the webcams hub)?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012team

________________________________

Liz, that's exactly right, we need a success page (or any event that can be treated as success)
The secondary version of the homepage is waiting to go live, so we can get the experiment started as soon as there's a success page or event.

"Figure out which page of your site represents 'success' - it could be a purchase or enquiry confirmation depending on the business type. Once you start testing your variation pages, WO will measure what proportion of visitors who see each variation go on to reach your conversion page. In this way, you'll be able to see which page is producing the best results for you (sales, leads etc)."

If this is about making the webcams more popular, I'd suggest the webcam page as success page - but the more conversion-like, the better.

Ok, cool. For this, I do think the webcam page is the right success
page, though we should definitely think more about what 'success' means
if we try this again in future!

 

Do you need me to set that up, or are you already in GA?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________

Liz, I'm closing your other ticket about A/B testing, and quick update here:

The experiment is running and inconclusive (webcams in the middle is sliiiiightly better than the original, but the difference is v small). But I've accidentally put the experiment to the wrong account, this is being resolved at the moment.

Ah, ok. Will I be able to see the results from the last week when you
move it to the right account?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

https://www.google.com/analytics/siteopt/settings?experiment=EAAAAAf5F94K-wBY6SOPBxhwDV4&account=1925888
 
Also attaching reports from the wrong account.
If you click on the above link, it now shows the data - the difference is hardly measurable, less than a percent.

FYI, if you have a look at http://google.com/websiteoptimizer - you can see there's a winner now - it's the version where we have the webcam in the middle of the page. I think something is not quite right with the conversion rates, but it doesn't change the result of the experiment.

If based on the experiment you decide to put the new version live, I'd be more than happy to get rid of the javascript that runs the A/B testing and the old version of the page.

Hmm...the conversion rate does indeed look very wrong. There's still
only a .6% difference... That can't possibly be as conclusive as their
green 'winner' mark seems to indicate, can it?

Ahh, got it. I will discuss at today's meeting with the rest of the
team - may make sense to change it, then!

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com

Cool. So. What I think we'd like to do is alter the experiment to now
set the goal page to the news landing page to see if it has an adverse
affect on news if we do switch the news/blog vs webcams/video. Does
that make sense?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________

Right. Could we make an other experiment measuring the news pages as conversions? Yes. Would it be very sensible to compare them with the current results? I think it would be a bit of a moving target. This experiment was to increase the number of visits to the webcams page, and as such it was a half success: there /was/ measurable difference, but it was tiny-tiny. An experience like this should show something like 20% difference between two versions. I'd be overjoyed with 5%.

If, however, as you're suggesting, the aim is to improve the number of -any- clickthroughs (that stay on london2012.com), we could do a completely different experiment saying the conversion is 'user clicks somewhere leaving the homepage and arriving to another page'. This is still not ideal, but we can give it a try.

Danny mentioned there are some KPIs kicking around, and what would be really exciting is to do a testing based on one of those. (Speculation follows:) I suspect there is 'number of new registrations' is on the list. (Oh, what's more, we're measuring the number of registrations and the confirmed registrations as well!) I think there might be some work involved in setting up the funnel properly so you can see where are losing users in the registration process - based on that, we could do some really killer a/b testing to improve the funnel. If you think it might be interesting, I'm happy to detail it in a new story.

The point of changing it to news is to make sure that the 'win' for
webcams isn't too much of a 'lose' for news. If it IS, then we'll need
to make an organisational decision about which is more important! I'm
hopeful that there is no real difference, so we'll then switch the page
to help the webcams, but I want to be sure, first!

 

The registration point is a good one - I've set up a very basic funnel,
but have never really looked much more into it. Do you have suggestions
on that front?

 

Liz Goulding

I'll have a look at them (attached) but when you see them I think you'll
understand the problem...there really aren't many around the main site
that aren't associated with some campaign or games-time. Sign-in is
clearly a good one, though.

From: Paul Deighton 
Sent: 19 March 2010 12:07
To: #LOCOG All Staff Members
Subject: London 2012 appoints Next as sponsor

 

Dear all,

 

I am delighted to inform you that Next have been appointed as Official Clothing and Homeware Supplier to London 2012 and have become our 27th domestic sponsor.

 

The press release with further details is below. 

 

Kind regards

 

Paul

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

19 March 2010

London 2012 appoints Next sponsor

 

- Next becomes London 2012's 27th sponsor

- Will supply clothing to athletes & officials

 

The London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games (LOCOG) has confirmed that Next has been appointed as Official Clothing and Homeware Supplier to London 2012 and has become its 27th domestic sponsor. 

 

Next will design outfits for the opening and closing ceremonies and formal suits for Team GB and Paralympics GB for the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games in 2012. In addition Next will produce formal uniforms for the 4,500 technical officials required for the Games, as well as suits for LOCOG's reception staff. 

 

Next will also supply some of the home furnishings and linen required in the Athletes' Village. 

As part of this partnership with LOCOG, Next will become a LOCOG licensee and Next will use its Creative Team to develop a commercial range of London 2012 clothing and homeware product. 

 

London 2012 Commercial Director Chris Townsend commented, "I'm thrilled that another fantastic British brand has joined us on our journey to 2012. Next is a great brand and I'm confident Next will create a great look for the athletes, officials and staff as well as helping us to make London 2012 product available across the country. We welcome them aboard."

 

Christos Angelides, Executive Director, Next Plc, says "The London 2012 Games is a once in a lifetime opportunity. We are excited at the prospect of working with the BOA, BPA and LOCOG Team. We are all proud of the British athletes and look forward to helping in a small way to make them look great at the Olympic and Paralympic ceremonies. As the official clothing and homeware licensee we look forward to providing our customers with exclusive access to a range of clothing and homeware that reflects the excitement and atmosphere of the London 2012 Olympic Games and Paralympic Games."

 

Next's partnership with London 2012 begins with immediate effect.


- Ends -

 

For further information please contact the London 2012 Press Office on +44 (0)203 2012 100 or visit the website at www.london2012.com. Find out the latest from London 2012 HQ on our blog http://blog.london2012.com  or follow us on Twitter http://www.twitter.com/london2012 

Notes to editors: 

 

As it heads towards its 2bn budget for staging the Olympic and Paralympic Games, LOCOG has seven domestic Tier One Partners - adidas, BMW, BP, British Airways, BT, EDF and Lloyds TSB. There are six domestic Tier Two Supporters - Adecco, Cadbury, Cisco, Deloitte, Thomas Cook and UPS. There are now fourteen domestic Tier Three Suppliers and Providers - Airwave, Atkins, Boston Consulting Group, Crystal CG, Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer LLP, GSK, Holiday Inn, John Lewis, McCann Worldgroup, Next, The Nielsen Company, Populous, Ticketmaster and Trident. 

 

The Worldwide Olympic Partners signed up for London 2012 are Coca-Cola, Acer, Atos Origin, GE, McDonald's, Omega, Panasonic, Samsung and Visa.

Hi Liz,

Before we start work on the front end we would like to get sign off on both the visual designs mock-ups and where we place them.

http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/254

In terms of design/placement we have three options:

- Option 1 (in context / near content) 

Putting the share widget close to the actual content we want the user to share ie. under the title/sidebar. This would involve more work than agreed as we'd need to align the widget to every type of content we have.

No screen shot as we don't think this is a practical route atm  but hopefully you can imagine what we are talking about.

- Option 2 (footer)

Putting the share widget on the bottom of the page as per the original design (although this was only supplied in a closed / single icon state)

This can be put to everywhere (as every page has a footer). However it's on a blindspot location, one needs to scroll to the very bottom of the page to find it. 

The attached screen has two states i) is if the 'share this page' text is clicked on the second ii) is if the 'email a friend' link is selected (the default closed stare isn't shown, but is just the icon and text on the bar)



- Option 3 (a new tab in global navigation)

This involves an additional menu item in the top menu. Works the same as the other drop down menu items, so no additional learning curve for the user to use the feature. Slightly changed tab color indicates it's
a bit different functionality than the actual menu, and draws the attention to it. The drop down menu give us more scope to fit in functionality to tie in with to socials networks (ie. an invite your friends functionality later on). 

The attached screen has two states i) one is the standard closed state the second ii) is the 'email a friend' box



Both options 1 and 2 have a similar implementation costs so it's really down to which one you think has the most benefit / least impact on key elements of the design.

I'm personally leaning towards 3, but need to make sure you are happy with spacing once the shop tab is reinstated as it woudl fill the top bar.

In all of my experiments, in FF & IE7, the alt text does appear in the published pages in these situations.

Currently, when you edit a Blog post, if you include an image inline, then that image's alt-text is displayed in the editor; you can leave it, if you're happy with it, or you can amend it - your amended alt-text only appears on this page though.

When you edit a page using the regular Page editor, if you upload an image into a picture container, then the alt text is NOT auto-populated for you. You /can/ still insert your own custom alt text. If you enter nothing, though, then the image gets rendered with whatever alt text was specified when it was uploaded. (*1) In fact, if open the page again in the page editor, the image's alt text appears as you might expect.

I'm not sure which of the above is the intended/prefered behaviour.

I haven't observed any problem whereby alt text is actually /lost/.
There /is/ an argument for auto-populating the alt-text control in the (regular) page editor (*2), to make what is going on more obvious. Expecially given that this is how the Blog editor works and also because of (*1).

Am forwarding to Janos.
